docs.lead_paragraph: In March 1912, two months after reaching the South Pole, Capt. Robert F. Scott froze to death in a tent just 11 miles from a depot of food and heating oil. His arrival at the pole, with four of his men, had been a bitter disappointment, for they were not the first to make it there. A Norwegian team led by Roald Amundsen had beaten them by a month.

headline.main: How Bad Luck Tipped the Scales to Disaster

docs.abstract: Dr Susan Solomon writes book on Capt Robert F Scott's ill-fated expedition to South Pole in 1912 that challenges prevailing view that he was a bungler and that attributes its failure chiefly to unusually frigid Antarctic weather that year; Roland Huntford, whose 1979 book on Scott and Roald Amundsen largely shaped current disparaging view of Scott, is unmoved by Solomon's findings; her book is The Coldest March; photos; chart; map (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco signed legislation yesterday that will require health insurers to pay for all costs related to Pap smears and similar tests used to detect cervical cancer. According to the bill's sponsors, previous legislation required insurers to cover only initial testing, creating a loophole for private insurers and health maintenance organizations to avoid payment. Making sure that follow-up Pap smears are covered by insurance is ''a no-brainer,'' said Senator Shirley K. Turner, a Ewing Democrat and one of the bill's sponsors.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Pap Smear Bill Signed

docs.abstract: New Jersey Acting Gov Donald T DiFrancesco signs legislation that will require health insurers to pay for all costs related to Pap smears and similar tests used to detect cervical cancer; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Signaling a new and potentially risky strategy, Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi turned an already nasty dispute with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani into a head-on personal confrontation yesterday, calling Mr. Giuliani a lame-duck Republican who is trying to disrupt the Democratic mayoral primary with ''pathetic lies.'' The indirect exchange between Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Giuliani -- they each held news conferences that were dominated by the flare-up -- began as a rerun of a pattern that has been playing itself out for nearly a week, in which the mayor attacks Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Hevesi rebuts the specific criticism. But the comptroller seemed intent yesterday on breaking that pattern by broadening and intensifying the battle.
docs.abstract: New York City Comptroller Alan G Hevesi turns already nasty dispute with Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani into head-on personal confrontation, calling Giuliani lame-duck Republican who is trying to disrupt Democratic mayoral primary with 'pathetic lies'; Giuliani tells reporters that Hevesi does not tell truth when responding to question about Hevesi's call for Giuliani and City Council Speaker Peter Vallone to give more money to public schools (M)
docs.snippet: Signaling a new and potentially risky strategy, Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi turned an already nasty dispute with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani into a head-on personal confrontation yesterday, calling Mr. Giuliani a lame-duck Republican who is trying to...

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's ethnic and racial minorities face large and troubling disparities in mental health care, the surgeon general said yesterday in a broad and comprehensive report that offers a rare look at the mental-health needs of four minority groups and the obstacles to treatment. Minorities in the United States, the surgeon general, Dr. David Satcher, said, ''suffer a disproportionate burden of mental illness'' because they often have less access to services than other Americans, receive lower quality care and are less likely to seek help when they are in distress.

headline.main: Disparities Seen In Mental Care For Minorities

docs.abstract: Surgeon General David Satcher issues broad, comprehensive report on mental health-needs of minority groups and obstacles to treatment; says they suffer disproportionate burden of mental illness because they often have less access to services than other Americans, receive lower quality care and are less likely to seek help when in distress; says while serious mental disorders occur in all races, ethnicities and socioeconomic classes, minorities tend to be overrepresented among those most vulnerable and in need of mental health treatment; says because of stigma attached to mental illness in some minority cultures, there is often reluctance to use services even when available; calls for more research in area that has been little studied and for more cultural awareness on part of mental health professionals; recommends increased efforts to address needs of minorities in shaping delivery of services, educating public and integrating mental health treatment with general medical care; report focuses on mental health concerns of African-Americans, Hispanic-Americans, Asian-Americans and Pacific Islanders, and American Indians and Alaska Natives (M)
docs.snippet: The nation's ethnic and racial minorities face large and troubling disparities in mental health care, the surgeon general said yesterday in a broad and comprehensive report that offers a rare look at the mental-health needs of four minority groups ...

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Health Service will pay for patients to be treated abroad, a sharp change of policy to deal with long waiting lists, Health Secretary Alan Milburn said today. The Department of Health said the European Court of Justice had forced the change by ruling that patients could seek treatment in other European Union countries if they face ''undue delay'' at home.

headline.main: Britain to Pay for Treatment Abroad

docs.abstract: Britain's Health Sec Alan Milburn says National Health Service will pay for patients to be treated abroad, sharp change of policy to deal with long waiting lists (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Alan G. Hevesi was on the steps of City Hall the other day, accepting an endorsement from the teachers' union -- and fielding questions about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's latest attacks on his ethics -- when a ''Hevesi'' placard suddenly slipped off his microphone stand and fluttered toward the ground. Mr. Hevesi grinned gamely toward the television cameras. ''Don't read any symbolism into that,'' he said, as he reaffixed the drooping sign. ''Every time we're down, we get up.''

headline.main: Closing In on a Moving Target; As Mayoral Primary Nears, the Democrats Inject a bit of Drama

docs.abstract: Overview of New York City's desultory Democratic mayoral primary campaign, which has not captured attention of electorate; highlights of campaigns of Mark Green, Alan Hevesi, Fernando Ferrer and Peter Vallone; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN his private conference room, tucked away beside his formal Midtown Manhattan office, Henry R. Kravis keeps a framed quotation: ''There is nothing more difficult to take in hand, more perilous to conduct, or more uncertain in its outcome, than to take the lead in introducing a new order of things.'' The line, from Niccolo Machiavelli, speaks to the image as a financial innovator that Mr. Kravis and his investment firm, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, have always cultivated. In the merger mania of the 1980's, Kohlberg Kravis did more than any other firm to popularize the leveraged buyout -- the use of huge amounts of debt, typically a mix of junk bonds, bank loans and a little cash, to buy public companies and take them private.
docs.abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts struggles to adjust to changes in world of leveraged buyouts, which it pioneered in 1980's; field it once dominated now has dozens of competitors, some boasting much higher returns to KKR's; weakening economy has also made it harder for firm to raise debt needed to finance deals; firm's returns have also been dragged down by several investments that went sour, notably $1.6 billion investment in Regal Cinemas; disappointing performance of RJR Nabisco buyout, which made firm's reputation in 1989, continues to hurt its track record; comments from Henry R Kravis and George R Roberts, founders and partners; photos; graph (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To coax skittish young Saudis into working on an assembly line churning out 300,000 packages of cookies a day, the managers at the National Biscuits & Confectionery Company have learned to maintain a certain degree of flexibility -- and patience. One Saudi man objected to wearing overalls, embarrassed when acquaintances rolled down their car windows and joked that he should avoid police patrols looking for illegal immigrants. Another disliked the job title of laborer assigned to the roughly $6,000 per year entry job, wanting to tell his new bride he was a technician. A third insisted that he belonged in management, not production.

headline.main: Leisure Class to Working Class in Saudi Arabia

docs.abstract: Article in series, The Perils of Plenty, examines situation in Saudi Arabia, where virtually everyone was lifted out of poverty with oil revenues, but now petrodollars do not stretch as far and many incredulous Saudis confront fact that they will have to work at real jobs; baby boom generation spawned by 1970's oil wealth is wading into job market that can only generate one job for every two men; country must find ways to relax its rigid traditions to make economy grow; it needs jobs for new generation whose parents did not have to work; future may hinge on unresolved question of how to pass down absolute monarchy once all 44 sons of founder, King Abdel Azis al-Saud, are gone; photos; map. graphs (L)
docs.snippet: To coax skittish young Saudis into working on an assembly line churning out 300,000 packages of cookies a day, the managers at the National Biscuits & Confectionery Company have learned to maintain a certain degree of flexibility -- and patience.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: BY 9 a.m. on most days, Dr. George Berk's new waiting room is thick with quiet anxiety. Glossy publicity stills of movie stars like Bette Davis and Cary Grant hang on the walls, oozing nonchalance, but that doesn't seem to relax the dozen or more people in their 40's and 50's who sit silently, waiting to hear the worst. They have been brought here not by a doctor's recommendation, by chest pain or the discovery of an ominous lump, but by a radio ad. On a recent weekday morning, most seemed stunningly healthy, glowing with late-summer tans beneath their furrowed brows. Up from New York City or down from Westchester and Connecticut suburbs, they have come to this small office in White Plains armed with suspicions and checkbooks.
docs.abstract: Article on cardiologist George Berk of White Plains, NY, one of growing number of physicians whose staffs perform full-body electron beam tomography on clients who consider themselves healthy but worry about disease; tests, performed by modified CT scanner, produce detailed views of all organs and blood vessels, cost average of $900, are not covered by insurance and have only recently begun to be popular on east coast; photo (M)
